defs.docs: The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL context on as many platforms as possible.

attributes.value: ! The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL context on as many platforms as possible.
! # Building a GlWindow
! A `GlWindow` is composed of a `Window` and an OpenGL `Context`. Due to some
! operating-system-specific quirks, glutin requires control over the order of creation of the
! `Context` and `Window`. Here is an example of building a GlWindow:
! ```no_run
! # extern crate glutin;
! # fn main() {
! let events_loop = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
! let window = glutin::WindowBuilder::new()
!     .with_title("Hello world!")
!     .with_dimensions(glutin::dpi::LogicalSize::new(1024.0, 768.0));
! let context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new();
! let gl_window = glutin::GlWindow::new(window, context, &events_loop).unwrap();
! # Features
! This crate has one Cargo feature: `window`.
!  - `window` allows you to create regular windows and enables the `WindowBuilder` object.
! By default `window` is enabled.

defs.docs: Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.

attributes.value: ! Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.
! Contains the following modules:
!  - `android`
!  - `ios`
!  - `macos`
!  - `unix`
!  - `windows`

cfg(any(target_os = "linux", target_os = "dragonfly", target_os = "freebsd",
          target_os = "openbsd"))

defs.name: Context
defs.docs: Represents an OpenGL context.

attributes.value: / Represents an OpenGL context.
/ A `Context` is normally associated with a single Window, however `Context`s can be *shared*
/ between multiple windows.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ # extern crate glutin;
/ # use glutin::GlContext;
/ # fn main() {
/ # let events_loop = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
/ # let window = glutin::WindowBuilder::new();
/ # let context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new();
/ # let some_gl_window = glutin::GlWindow::new(window, context, &events_loop).unwrap();
/ let context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new()
/     .with_vsync(true)
/     .with_multisampling(8)
/     .with_shared_lists(some_gl_window.context());

defs.docs: Object that allows you to build `Context`s.

attributes.value: / Object that allows you to build `Context`s.

defs.docs: The attributes to use to create the context.

defs.name: GlWindow
defs.docs: Represents an OpenGL context and a Window with which it is associated.

attributes.value: / Represents an OpenGL context and a Window with which it is associated.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ # extern crate glutin;
/ # use glutin::GlContext;
/ # fn main() {
/ let mut events_loop = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
/ let window = glutin::WindowBuilder::new();
/ let context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new();
/ let gl_window = glutin::GlWindow::new(window, context, &events_loop).unwrap();
/ unsafe { gl_window.make_current().unwrap() };
/ loop {
/     events_loop.poll_events(|event| {
/         match event {
/             // process events here
/     // draw everything here
/     gl_window.swap_buffers();
/     std::thread::sleep(std::time::Duration::from_millis(17));

/ This option will be taken into account on the following platforms:
/   * MacOS
/   * Linux using GLX with X
/   * Windows using WGL
inline

defs.docs: Sets whether hardware acceleration is required.

attributes.value: / Sets whether hardware acceleration is required.
/ The default value is `Some(true)`
/ ## Platform-specific
/ This option will be taken into account on the following platforms:
/   * MacOS
/   * Linux using EGL with either X or Wayland
/   * Windows using EGL or WGL
/   * Android using EGL
inline

defs.name: new
defs.value: fn (window_builder: WindowBuilder, context_builder: ContextBuilder, events_loop: &EventsLoop) -> Result<Self, CreationError>
defs.docs:
Builds the given window along with the associated GL context, returning the pair as a
 `GlWindow`.

attributes.value: / Builds the given window along with the associated GL context, returning the pair as a
/ `GlWindow`.
/ The context made can be shared with:
/  - headless contexts made with the `shareable_with_windowed_contexts`
/  flag set to `true`; and
/  - contexts made when creating a `GlWindow`.
/ You are not guaranteed to receive an error if you share a context with an
/ other context which you're not permitted to share it with, as according
/ to:
/  - the restrictions stated by us above; and
/  - the restrictions imposed on you by the platform your application runs
/  on. (Please refer to `README-SHARING.md`)
/ Failing to follow all the context sharing restrictions imposed on you
/ may result in unsafe behavior.
/ This safe variant of `new_shared` will panic if you try to share it with
/ an existing context.
/ Error should be very rare and only occur in case of permission denied,
/ incompatible system out of memory, etc.

defs.docs: Borrow the inner `Window`.

attributes.value: / Borrow the inner `Window`.

defs.docs: Borrow the inner GL `Context`.

attributes.value: / Borrow the inner GL `Context`.

defs.name: swap_buffers
defs.docs: Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.

attributes.value: / Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.
/ You should call this function every time you have finished rendering, or the image may not
/ be displayed on the screen.
/ **Warning**: if you enabled vsync, this function will block until the next time the screen
/ is refreshed. However drivers can choose to override your vsync settings, which means that
/ you can't know in advance whether `swap_buffers` will block or not.

defs.name: get_pixel_format
defs.docs: Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

attributes.value: / Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

defs.name: resize
defs.docs: Resize the context.

attributes.value: / Resize the context.
/ Some platforms (macOS, Wayland) require being manually updated when their window or
/ surface is resized.
/ The easiest way of doing this is to take every `Resized` window event that
/ is received with a `LogicalSize` and convert it to a `PhysicalSize` and
/ pass it into this function.

defs.name: new
defs.value: fn (el: &winit::EventsLoop, context_builder: ContextBuilder, shareable_with_windowed_contexts: bool) -> Result<Self, CreationError>
defs.docs: Builds the given GL context

attributes.value: / Builds the given GL context
/ Contexts made with the `shareable_with_windowed_contexts` flag set to
/ `true` can be shared with:
/  - contexts made with that flag set to `true`; and
/  - contexts made when creating a `GlWindow`.
/ If the flag is set to `false` on the other hand, the context should only
/ be shared with other contexts made with the flag set to `false`.
/ Some platforms might not implement contexts which aren't shareable with
/ windowed contexts. If so, those platforms will fallback to making a
/ contexts which are shareable with windowed contexts.
/ You are not guaranteed to receive an error if you share a context with an
/ other context which you're not permitted to share it with, as according
/ to:
/  - the restrictions stated by us above; and
/  - the restrictions imposed on you by the platform your application runs
/  on. (Please refer to `README-SHARING.md`)
/ Failing to follow all the context sharing restrictions imposed on you
/ may result in unsafe behavior.
/ This safe variant of `new_shared` will panic if you try to share it with
/ an existing context.
/ Error should be very rare and only occur in case of permission denied,
/ incompatible system, out of memory, etc.

/ If the flag is set to `false` on the other hand, the context should only
/ be shared with other contexts made with the flag set to `false`.
/ Some platforms might not implement contexts which aren't shareable with
/ windowed contexts. If so, those platforms will fallback to making a

/ You are not guaranteed to receive an error if you share a context with an
/ other context which you're not permitted to share it with, as according

defs.docs: Request a specific version of a specific API.

/ Example: `GlRequest::Specific(Api::OpenGl, (3, 3))`.

defs.name: GlThenGles
defs.docs:
If OpenGL is available, create an OpenGL context with the specified `opengl_version`.
 Else if OpenGL ES or WebGL is available, create a context with the
 specified `opengles_version`.

attributes.value: / If OpenGL is available, create an OpenGL context with the specified `opengl_version`.
/ Else if OpenGL ES or WebGL is available, create a context with the
/ specified `opengles_version`.

attributes.value: / Describes the OpenGL API and version that are being requested when a context is created.

defs.name: to_gl_version
defs.docs: Extract the desktop GL version, if any.

attributes.value: / Extract the desktop GL version, if any.

defs.name: GL_CORE
defs.docs:
The minimum core profile GL context. Useful for getting the minimum
 required GL version while still running on OSX, which often forbids
 the compatibility profile features.

attributes.value: / The minimum core profile GL context. Useful for getting the minimum
/ required GL version while still running on OSX, which often forbids
/ the compatibility profile features.

defs.name: NotRobust
defs.docs:
Not everything is checked. Your application can crash if you do something wrong with your
 shaders.

attributes.value: / Not everything is checked. Your application can crash if you do something wrong with your
/ shaders.

defs.name: NoError
defs.docs:
The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous. Please know what you're
 doing before using it. See the `GL_KHR_no_error` extension.

attributes.value: / The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous. Please know what you're
/ doing before using it. See the `GL_KHR_no_error` extension.
/ Since this option is purely an optimization, no error will be returned if the backend
/ doesn't support it. Instead it will automatically fall back to `NotRobust`.

defs.name: RobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to avoid any problem,
 but if a problem occurs the behavior is implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not
 to get a crash.

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to avoid any problem,
/ but if a problem occurs the behavior is implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not
/ to get a crash.

defs.name: TryRobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Same as `RobustNoResetNotification` but the context creation doesn't fail if it's not
 supported.

attributes.value: / Same as `RobustNoResetNotification` but the context creation doesn't fail if it's not
/ supported.

defs.name: RobustLoseContextOnReset
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the context will enter a
 "context lost" state. It must then be recreated. For the moment, glutin doesn't provide a
 way to recreate a context with the same window :-/

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the context will enter a
/ "context lost" state. It must then be recreated. For the moment, glutin doesn't provide a
/ way to recreate a context with the same window :-/

defs.name: TryRobustLoseContextOnReset
defs.docs:
Same as `RobustLoseContextOnReset` but the context creation doesn't fail if it's not
 supported.

attributes.value: / Same as `RobustLoseContextOnReset` but the context creation doesn't fail if it's not
/ supported.

defs.name: Robustness
defs.value: Robustness::{NotRobust, NoError, RobustNoResetNotification, TryRobustNoResetNotification, RobustLoseContextOnReset, TryRobustLoseContextOnReset}
defs.docs:
Specifies the tolerance of the OpenGL context to faults. If you accept raw OpenGL commands
 and/or raw shader code from an untrusted source, you should definitely care about this.

attributes.value: / Specifies the tolerance of the OpenGL context to faults. If you accept raw OpenGL commands
/ and/or raw shader code from an untrusted source, you should definitely care about this.

defs.name: None
defs.docs: Doesn't do anything. Most notably doesn't flush.

attributes.value: / Doesn't do anything. Most notably doesn't flush.

defs.name: Flush
defs.docs: Flushes the context that was previously current as if `glFlush` was called.

attributes.value: / Flushes the context that was previously current as if `glFlush` was called.

defs.name: ReleaseBehavior
defs.docs: The behavior of the driver when you change the current context.

attributes.value: / The behavior of the driver when you change the current context.

defs.docs: Describes a possible format. Unused.

attributes.value: / Describes a possible format. Unused.
allow(missing_docs)

defs.name: PixelFormatRequirements
defs.value: PixelFormatRequirements { hardware_accelerated, color_bits, float_color_buffer, alpha_bits, depth_bits, stencil_bits, double_buffer, multisampling, stereoscopy, srgb, release_behavior }
defs.docs: Describes how the backend should choose a pixel format.

attributes.value: / Describes how the backend should choose a pixel format.

defs.name: hardware_accelerated
defs.docs:
If true, only hardware-accelerated formats will be considered. If false, only software
 renderers. `None` means "don't care". Default is `Some(true)`.

attributes.value: / If true, only hardware-accelerated formats will be considered. If false, only software
/ renderers. `None` means "don't care". Default is `Some(true)`.

defs.name: color_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the color buffer, excluding alpha. `None` means "don't care".
 The default is `Some(24)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the color buffer, excluding alpha. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default is `Some(24)`.

defs.name: float_color_buffer
defs.docs: If true, the color buffer must be in a floating point format. Default is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, the color buffer must be in a floating point format. Default is `false`.
/ Using floating points allows you to write values outside of the `[0.0, 1.0]` range.

defs.name: alpha_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the alpha in the color buffer. `None` means "don't care".
 The default is `Some(8)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the alpha in the color buffer. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default is `Some(8)`.

defs.name: depth_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
 The default value is `Some(24)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default value is `Some(24)`.

defs.name: stencil_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
 The default value is `Some(8)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default value is `Some(8)`.

defs.name: double_buffer
defs.docs:
If true, only double-buffered formats will be considered. If false, only single-buffer
 formats. `None` means "don't care". The default is `Some(true)`.

attributes.value: / If true, only double-buffered formats will be considered. If false, only single-buffer
/ formats. `None` means "don't care". The default is `Some(true)`.

defs.name: multisampling
defs.docs:
Contains the minimum number of samples per pixel in the color, depth and stencil buffers.
 `None` means "don't care". Default is `None`.
 A value of `Some(0)` indicates that multisampling must not be enabled.

attributes.value: / Contains the minimum number of samples per pixel in the color, depth and stencil buffers.
/ `None` means "don't care". Default is `None`.
/ A value of `Some(0)` indicates that multisampling must not be enabled.

defs.name: stereoscopy
defs.docs:
If true, only stereoscopic formats will be considered. If false, only non-stereoscopic
 formats. The default is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, only stereoscopic formats will be considered. If false, only non-stereoscopic
/ formats. The default is `false`.

defs.name: srgb
defs.docs:
If true, only sRGB-capable formats will be considered. If false, don't care.
 The default is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, only sRGB-capable formats will be considered. If false, don't care.
/ The default is `false`.

defs.name: release_behavior
defs.docs: The behavior when changing the current context. Default is `Flush`.

attributes.value: / The behavior when changing the current context. Default is `Flush`.

defs.name: GlAttributes
defs.value: GlAttributes { sharing, version, profile, debug, robustness, vsync }
defs.docs: Attributes to use when creating an OpenGL context.

attributes.value: / Attributes to use when creating an OpenGL context.

defs.name: sharing
defs.docs: An existing context to share the new the context with.

attributes.value: / An existing context to share the new the context with.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: version
defs.docs: Version to try create. See `GlRequest` for more infos.

attributes.value: / Version to try create. See `GlRequest` for more infos.
/ The default is `Latest`.

defs.name: profile
defs.docs: OpenGL profile to use.

attributes.value: / OpenGL profile to use.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: debug
defs.docs: Whether to enable the `debug` flag of the context.

attributes.value: / Whether to enable the `debug` flag of the context.
/ Debug contexts are usually slower but give better error reporting.
/ The default is `true` in debug mode and `false` in release mode.

defs.name: robustness
defs.docs: How the OpenGL context should detect errors.

attributes.value: / How the OpenGL context should detect errors.
/ The default is `NotRobust` because this is what is typically expected when you create an
/ OpenGL context. However for safety you should consider `TryRobustLoseContextOnReset`.

defs.name: vsync
defs.docs:
Whether to use vsync. If vsync is enabled, calling `swap_buffers` will block until the
 screen refreshes. This is typically used to prevent screen tearing.

attributes.value: / Whether to use vsync. If vsync is enabled, calling `swap_buffers` will block until the
/ screen refreshes. This is typically used to prevent screen tearing.
/ The default is `false`.

defs.name: map_sharing
defs.docs: Turns the `sharing` parameter into another type by calling a closure.

attributes.value: / Turns the `sharing` parameter into another type by calling a closure.
inline
